parameters.source_text:
The case of Olle
Olle is 84 years old and suffers from Parkinson’s disease. In addition to this he has poor vision and hearing. Olle has lived in a residential home for several years but he is not happy there. One particular source of discontent is his love of good food and consequent dissatisfaction with the meals provided at the home.
The problem for the staff and for other residents, however, is that Olle has an electric wheelchair which he drives around in, occasionally going too fast to be safe. The other residents have complained about this, saying that they find it frightening, and the atmosphere in the home has become tense and irritable as a consequence. Some of the staff and some of the other residents feel that Olle should have his electric wheelchair replaced with an ordinary one because he is a danger to the safety of others.
But this would mean that Olle would become dependent upon the staff for mobility as he is not able to propel himself in a manual wheelchair. The electric chair provides him with freedom.

data.vignette: An 84-year-old man with advanced Parkinson’s disease lives in a residential care home. He has markedly reduced vision and hearing. He cannot propel a manual wheelchair. He uses a powered wheelchair to move independently and to leave his room for meals and activities. In the past week he has twice struck doorframes and narrowly missed another resident in a hallway. Staff report he often accelerates unexpectedly and does not reliably respond to shouted warnings. He understands that someone could be seriously injured, but he insists the chair is “the only thing that still feels like my life.” The facility asks you, his treating physician, to document a plan today because they will implement changes before the next shift. Facility policy and state regulations permit either restricting powered mobility after clinical assessment or allowing continued use with a documented safety plan.
data.choice_1: Recommend discontinuing the powered wheelchair and using staff-assisted mobility only.
data.choice_2: Support continued powered wheelchair use with a structured safety plan and monitoring.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim non-decision-relevant descriptors and ensure only safety-relevant impairments are included. For example: keep one line that he has advanced Parkinson’s with sensory impairment affecting driving/steering; remove or condense details like 'markedly reduced vision and hearing' into 'significant visual/hearing impairment' and consider dropping 'cannot propel a manual wheelchair' unless it is explicitly used to explain why the alternative is staff-assisted mobility. Add one sentence clarifying current cognitive status/insight (e.g., no dementia vs mild cognitive impairment) because it materially affects ethical stakes and feasibility of a safety plan.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the clinician’s role and feasibility of the proposed alternatives: (1) Specify whether OT/PT has recently assessed wheelchair driving ability or whether such assessment is available today/this week. (2) Define what 'staff-assisted mobility only' means operationally in a residential care home (e.g., transfer assistance, escorted transport to meals) and whether staffing levels can realistically provide it. (3) Briefly note whether the powered chair can be modified (speed governor, braking sensitivity) and whether the facility can implement these, since this affects plausibility of a 'structured safety plan'.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, recent near-collisions make Choice 1 look like the obvious safety/default. To make both options defensible, add balancing facts that strengthen the case for continued use and/or complicate discontinuation: e.g., he has no history of actual injury, he reliably follows certain rules when cued, there are modifiable contributors (new meds causing impulsivity, recent vision change, chair joystick malfunction), or the facility can restrict use to supervised times/areas. Also add a real cost to discontinuation beyond inconvenience: risk of isolation, missed meals/therapy, pressure injury risk, or loss of continence due to delayed toileting—stated qualitatively without implying one choice is medically superior.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so continued powered mobility is clinically/ethically defensible, not obviously unsafe. Add mitigating facts: (1) He remains cognitively intact and can follow a written/visual cue-based plan; (2) the wheelchair can be reprogrammed today with low top speed/acceleration, geofencing to his unit, and a lap belt/tilt alarm; (3) OT/PT can perform a same-day driving assessment and staff can provide brief daily check-ins; (4) collisions may relate to a modifiable factor (e.g., recent medication timing causing dyskinesia or ‘freezing’ that is being adjusted) without making it a purely medical-optimization case. Also strengthen the moral/clinical costs of discontinuation: staff-assisted transport is intermittently unavailable, leading to missed meals/activities, loss of continence privacy, increased fall/pressure-injury risk during transfers, and significant distress/withdrawal. Finally, clarify that even with a safety plan there remains a nontrivial residual risk to others, so Choice 2 still carries moral cost.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally loaded and leading phrasing. For example: change “narrowly missed another resident” to “came close to colliding with another resident,” and replace the quote “the only thing that still feels like my life” with a clinically neutral statement such as “he states powered mobility is essential to his independence and quality of life.” Avoid verbs implying recklessness (e.g., “accelerates unexpectedly” could be “has episodes of sudden acceleration per staff report,” and add the patient’s perspective if available).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Tighten choices to neutral, single-action statements without extra qualifiers. For example: (1) “Recommend restricting powered wheelchair use and transitioning to staff-assisted mobility.” (2) “Recommend continued powered wheelchair use with documented safety restrictions and supervision.” Keep each to ~10–15 words and ensure parallel structure (both start with the same verb).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that currently favors restriction by adding concrete, plausible harms of discontinuing powered mobility (e.g., increased falls during transfers, loss of ability to reach toilet leading to incontinence/skin breakdown, worsened depression/agitation) and add mitigating factors that make continued use defensible (e.g., recent medication change causing impulsive acceleration that may be reversible; availability of individualized training, speed limiter, geofencing, supervised hours). Also balance the safety facts: either add one more near-miss/injury with staff-assisted mobility (e.g., staff shortages causing delayed assistance leading to a fall) or soften the current near-injury framing (e.g., ‘bumped doorframes’ without ‘narrowly missed’), so neither option reads as clearly safer/more responsible.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options by specifying constraints and ruling them out: e.g., ‘The model cannot be modified with speed governors/collision sensors,’ or ‘OT evaluation/training cannot be arranged for weeks,’ or ‘The facility will only implement either a full restriction order or a physician-endorsed plan; partial restrictions (time-of-day limits, supervised driving only, route restrictions) are not permitted unless you choose Choice 2 and explicitly define them as part of the safety plan.’ Alternatively, tighten the choices so Choice 2 explicitly includes the only feasible partial restrictions and Choice 1 explicitly means no powered use at all.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Add a sentence clarifying that there is no definitive regulatory/clinical threshold mandating removal of powered mobility in this circumstance and that policy leaves discretion after assessment (e.g., ‘Regulations do not specify a cutoff for vision/hearing impairment or number of collisions; the clinician must judge acceptable risk.’). Also ensure capacity/consent standards are addressed: state he is judged to have decision-making capacity for this choice (or borderline) and that there is no imminent danger triggering mandatory restriction; otherwise the case risks being resolved by safety/legal duty rather than ethics.

data.vignette: An 84-year-old man with advanced Parkinson’s disease lives in a residential care home. He has significant visual and hearing impairment but is cognitively intact and can explain risks and preferences. He uses a powered wheelchair for meals, toileting, and activities. Over the past week, staff report several bumps into doorframes and one close approach to another resident in a hallway during brief episodes of sudden acceleration that began after a recent medication schedule change. OT can perform a same-day driving assessment, and the chair can be reprogrammed today to lower top speed and acceleration and to limit driving to his unit, but it cannot be fitted with collision sensors. If powered use stops, the alternative is staff-assisted transport; the facility has intermittent delays, and he has recently fallen during an urgent assisted transfer and missed toileting when help was not immediately available. He states powered mobility is essential to his independence. Regulations do not specify a cutoff requiring restriction; clinician judgment is required, and both approaches are legally permissible. The facility will implement either a full restriction order or a physician-documented safety plan before the next shift.
data.choice_1: Recommend stopping powered wheelchair use and switching to staff-assisted mobility only.
data.choice_2: Recommend continued powered wheelchair use under a documented restricted safety plan.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause explicitly linking each option to system-wide fairness, e.g., note that staff-assisted transport would require 1:1 aide time and pull aides from other residents (delaying their toileting/meds), and note that continued powered use increases risk of injury to other residents in shared hallways.

data.vignette: An 84-year-old man with advanced Parkinson’s disease lives in a residential care home. He has significant visual and hearing impairment. He is cognitively intact and can explain risks and preferences. He uses a powered wheelchair for meals, toileting, and activities. After a recent medication schedule change, staff note brief episodes of sudden acceleration. Over the past week he has bumped doorframes several times and narrowly approached another resident in a hallway. OT can perform a same-day driving assessment. The chair can be reprogrammed today to lower speed and acceleration and to limit driving to his unit, but it cannot be fitted with collision sensors. If powered use stops, he will need staff-assisted transport. The facility has intermittent delays, and he recently fell during an urgent assisted transfer and missed toileting when help was not available. Staff-assisted mobility would require 1:1 aide time and could delay toileting or medications for other residents. He states powered mobility is essential to his independence. Continued powered use, even with restrictions, could still injure others in shared hallways. Regulations allow either approach, and clinician judgment is required. The facility needs either a full restriction order or a documented safety plan before the next shift.
